text: Black colour with brown foam. The taste is coffee and chocolate. I normally love this beer but the chili as not very present because of the barrel.
Bottle from ?? - pours pitchs with a chocolate head. Aroma is more whiskey barrel, oak, and vanilla then chipotle. Solid!

Bottle from unknown place. Pours pitch black with a thin khaki head. Some pepper notes on the nose along with a big roasted chocolate roast note. Not a lot of pepper on the tongue at this point or much whisky influence. Yet it's a really good porter with a nice hop note to go with the roasted malt. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle BB 2017, 375ml, 6.6%, picked up at Kris Wines about a year ago. Very dark brown, big dense foamy brown head, sparse lacing. Aroma is coconut, whisky, a little sour with some soft smoke. Body is medium, a little foamy, low carbonation. Taste is smooth malts, some tangy whisky and chili, chocolate, a touch metallic, breathy chili finish. Very good.

Bottle, 2011 vintage. Opaque black liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of chili, wood, whisky, coffee, licorice and light ash. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of toast, light ash, light chili and whisky. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Decent but probably too old.

Bottled. Pours black with a medium sized tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, peat, whiskey and chili notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry with and slightly bitter. Medium to full bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. A very nice brew indeed.

"nice use of the barrels, though Ive yet to have the base beer. nose is a little heavy on the scotch and porter, with the peppers barely making an appearance. chocolate, roast, peat...awesome aroma. flavor lets the peppers shine a little more, especially in the finish. smooth, light-medium bodied, especially for a barreled beer. another winner, albeit overpriced. "

375mL bottle; Holdbar til 17/08/17. Pours almost pitch black with a big, light brown cap. Aroma is vegetal, earthy, medicinal, chocolate chip cookies, molasses, wood, whiskey. Taste is vegetable sweetness and bitterness. Chewy dry finish.

Botella de 37.5 cl en casa. Junio de 2013 de 2d2dspuma.
Cuerpo medio  fuerte de color negro intenso y con espuma algo oscura no muy persistente.
Aromas tostados y quemados con especias y chiles y un toque final de madera de whisky de speyside.
Maravillosa porter en la que se nota el envejecido en whisky Speyside que ya no la hace tan seca y amarga sino que le da un toque dulce ajerezado- de pasas y madera. También algo más especiada que su hermana pequeña (Texas Ranger) y mucho menos picante que ella.
Para repetir sin dudarlo, increible.
Tap @ Fermentoren. 5/8 2013. Pitch black, small tan head, okay lacing that doesnt last. Roasted malts, speyside smoke, coffee sweet vanilla, chocolate. Similar taste, with a bit of chili.
Bottle. Boozy oaky sweet milk chocolate aroma. Black brown with a minimal tan head. Earthy smoky chocolate malt aroma. Medium body.

Bouteille de 375ml. b.b. 17/08/17. Bière brune foncée avec une mousse brune durable. Au nez cest boisé avec du chocolat et du whiskey. Cest un peu acide et fruité. La bouche est riche, crémeuse, pas trop boisé mais avec un peu de poussière en fin de bouche et ce remarquable goût de piment fort. Un succès.

Une bouteille de 37.5 cl. Gracieuseté de Kevin B. Meilleure avant le 17/08/17. Une présentation soignée. Une robe presque noire et une mousse brune qui tente la résistance. Un nez bien foncé et même impérial, tissé par lorge rôti, le caramel bien foncé et les douces transpirations du Speyside. Un goût bien relevé. Des saveurs chocolatées et des notes de mélasse. Des épices infusées dans un whisky enrobé. Une bouche densifiée, un pétillement modéré et une texture huileuse. Une finale qui laisse filer des notes de chipotle à travers des saveurs agréablement maltées et amères.  Voilà une bière dans laquelle les flaveurs du fût sont harmonieuses.

Black....thick with a thin tan head.
Aroma is chocolate, malt, pepper.
Taste is a little boozy, chocolate.
A little smoke, slight pepper sting.
Very nice.
Bottle.  Whisky and pepper aroma.  Black with minimal head - pours like motor oil.   Sweet chocolate malt, whiskey, and mild chipotle flavor.   Light ash finish.  No heat to speak of but very nice.

Bottle, 375ml. A dark brown, almost black beer topped by a dense, tan head of moderate size. Vanilla, some chili, and roasted matls and chocolate in the aroma. The flavor has more vanilla than Id expect, also it feels more vanilla-ish than the vanilla and cocoa edition. Roasted malts, booze and chocolate. Full body, with chili burn and roasted malts in the finish. A nice one, tasteful and pleasant, and dangerously easy drinkable. 120914
Bonne présence en bouche, caractère fûmé et chocolaté avec un touche de piquant en finale.

12.7 oz. bottle. Pours oily black brown with a large creamy foamy tan head that slowly settles to a film and lacing. Aroma has awesome bourbon whiskey scents with some sugar and yeast roasted malt. Taste has a subtle bitterness light whiskey bourbon notes and roasted malt and yeast some strange tartness with a very subtle spice on the finish. Palate is a little thin with a chalky dry finish. Really nice beer! I would buy another one if I saw it.

pours motor oil black with lots of coffee tan head. Smells sweet, rich and boozy, with lots of wood. Nice and smooth up front with almost a sweet wood and whiskey aftertaste. I dont get a ton of spice but that might be from the age of the bottle very interesting flavour non the less.

Having had the non-specific Barrel Aged some time ago (pre-Ratebeer) and declaring it one of the finest drinks available to humanity, i was understandably looking forward to this! Not sure I can detect what the Speyside casks have added - its still the lovely, rich, well-balanced drink I remember, with just a hint of heat coming through from the chilies tickling your tongue on the finish. The smoke works so well with the overall malt-bill, the hop bitterness is just right. Damn fine porter.

A - Dark black with a hint of brown and a thin finger of frothy khaki-chocolate colored head. Fades fairly quickly.

S - Sweet dark chocolate malts, oak, vanilla, whiskey, chipotle, roasted coffee, black licorice, bit of molasses, some booze.

T - Sweet dark chocolate malts, bit of milk chocolate, vanilla, oak, Whiskey lightly spicy chipotle peppers, roasted coffee, black licorice, molasses, and a bit of booze.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a spicy, warming, and sweet finish.

D - Nice spicy porter. The chipotle adds some nice heat and the barrel adds some nice complexity.

Pours an opaque black colour with a very fine light brown ring around the glass. Aromas of scotch, oak, chocolate, sweet maltiness. Flavours of chocolate, oak, lighter than the regular on the chipotle peppers, little coffee, smooth scotch flavour.

Pours a dark opaque black with a small brown ring.  Aroma is of wood, sweet fruits, malted whiskey & some peatiness.  Taste is oak, whiskey, faint coffee, sweet dried fruits and then chipotle pepper on the finish that gives a nice warming/burning in the back of your throat.  This barrel aged beer helps take the chipotle pepper edge off from the original and is exceptionally smooth.

Bottle from Barleywine. 
Pours dark brown with no head to speak of.
Aroma is pretty much like regular Texas Ranger, dark chocolate, loads of roasted malts, but with faint whiskey notes.
Taste is a lot like the regular version but almost completely lacks the chili after a few sips, quite strange. The barrel ageing added whiskey notes and some dry woody notes which sits nice with the other tastes but they could have been more prominent. Too bad that the chili wasnt that forward but perhaps it just was this bottle.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, whiskey, coffee. Flavour is oak, whiskey, coffee, roasted malt, chili, chocolate. Very nice beer.

(bottle) pours a pitch black colour with a light brown head. aroma of toasted malts, espresso and heavy vanilla, with a hint of smoke, chayenne pepper and ash. flavour is heavy ash and peat smoke, toasted malts, light dark chocolate and a light, lingering burn in the finish. slightly watery body with soft carbonation.
@ Mikkeller Bar: Mycket stor fatdoft, smaken faller bort lite, men trevlig kryddighet och ganska kladdig

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, November 2012.

Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma and taste of roasted malt, chocolate, whisky, wood, some fruit and pepper. A bit fuzzy but still a nice one.

375ml bottle, bottled 17/8/11. Pours pitch black with a small, intensely dark brown, big bubbled head that recedes quickly and leaves lace. Aromas of chocolate, roast, chilipeppers, slight smoke, dark fruit (dried plum and figs) and woody, oakish vanilla with a coating caramelly sweetness. Lots going on, nice. Taste is roasty, dark chocolate, chili, smoke, raisins and port with a slight chili burn in the aftertaste. The chocolate shows itself more as the beer warms up. Palate is surprisingly thick but not sirupy, medium to low carbonation, slightly oily. The Speyside barrel is clearly more prevalent in the aroma and not so in the taste, which was a lot like the regular version. Very nice.

On draft at Craft Beer Co. Id found the base beer to be solid and intense in its singular focus, with the chiles at times being a bit too potent. Somehow, perhaps improbably, the barrel aging here actually brings out some more subtlety in the base in addition to imparting its own flavors. Theres a pronounced chocolatey dimension to it that is enhanced here, balancing out the heat from the booze and subduing the chipotle a bit too. Very slight tannins stitch things together a bit, and theres a healthy smoke component to the brew too. Overall, quite nice.

Bottle 375ml @ Geokkjer
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chili, oak, chocolate and whiskey. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with a long chocolate, chili and spicy finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
At Borefts 2011. Poured dark brown, aroma of wood and chocolate malt. Full bodied, flavour of wood, chocolate malt and smooth coffee. Dry, full fruity aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours black with a creamy beige head. Aroma  of  roasted malt, chocolate, malt, fruitiness and whisky.  Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, roasted malt, smoked wood and chocolate. Medium to full body, average carbonation.

Keg at the Craft Beer Co., London. Pours deep brown with a small, beige foam head. Aroma holds some dark chocolate, hints of chili peppers, modest roast. Flavor is light to medium sweet with some dry wood, whiskey, and a good spicy chili kick. Light to medium bodied with fine carbonation. The spiciness picks up some speed in the finish but is pleasantly offset by some burnt, woody dryness and roasty cocoa. I wouldnt mind if the beer had a bit more body and sweetness, but pretty darn good as is.
(Bottle during RBWG) deep espresso brown, wispy tan bubbles. Nose of scotch, rich chocolate, and chipotle. Taste of rich whiskey, chipotle, smooth, fudge, chipotle linger, light carbonation.
Bottle thanks to dallas brew crew- Pour is dark black, with a tan head..nose is wood, spice , spice, whiskey..Taste is spice, whiskey,wood, earth,..Palate is wood and chocolate
Black color with tan head. Dry wood, dry chocolate, smoke aromas. medium body with soft co2. Mild pepper flavors with dark roast,  dry wood, dark chocolate--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: The pour is black in color with a tan head.  Aroma isnt very good.  Green apple, paint thinner, and alcohol.  Some roasted malt and maybe a bit of dark chocolate.  Really quite abrasive.  The flavor is a touch better than the nose, luckily.  Green apple, chocolate, roast, alcohol, and maybe just a hint of whiskey.  Theres a weird chlorine flavor to it, too.  I dont really get any of the peppers.  Too bad as the regular version was quite good.

Aroma big fruit cake nose with a wide variety of smells including molasses and lemons and dates
APPEARANCE  Midnight dark with a big chocolate head and great lacing
TASTE: Big roast and chocolate malts with dates and plums and  molasses in the finish absolutely delicious, marvelous Scotch finish and a almost cloying sweetness to be balanced off by hops- would cure malaria Im sure.
PALATE as big and thick as a beer can be with delectable hops right at the end pinching things up a bit
OVERALL absolutely superb beer with now known reason not to have another

350ml bottle bought at Lukens, poured a dark brown with some red highlights, aromas of chocolate, light chipotle, dark fruit, touch of roast, and a smidge of booze.  Flavors are the same, little vanilla thrown in there, not much heat from the peppers, and not much booze from the whiskey as I expected.

pours coffee black, small head, micro CO2 ringed retention. Coffee and heavy malts on the nose. Roasted coffee hits your first, followed by mocha, sweet chocolate, vanilla, cocoa nibs, all mixed with a creamy mouthfeel, and 5/10-level sweetness and coffee-like viscosity. Finish is soft and bittersweet. Medium-high complexity, high depth, excellent transitions, great carry, excellent drinkability. Sourness is expertly controlled leading to a smooth drinking and very sippable experience.

15/V/2012 - 37.5cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ Klaas place - BB: 17/VIII/17 (2012-503) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Dark deep brown to black beer, small dark brown head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots of mocha, very woody, some caramel, touch of vanilla, some cocoa powder, some whisky (could be my mind playing tricks though). MF: ok carbon, full to medium body. Taste: pretty sour start, some vinegar, mocha, caramel, bitter hops, some chillies. Aftertaste: caramel, some vanilla, chocolate, slight chilli burn, little bitter, alcohol is noticeable (which is weird at 6.6, I guess its the chillies fault!).

Thick blackness with a 3" dark crown floating on top. Sweet chocolaty roast aroma, with medium to light scotch, almost a soya sauce but never really develops fully. Taste is similar.....the barrel seems to have killed off most of the chipotle flavour but some heat shows up in the finish. What is this sweetness?? cherry? strawberry? mystery red popsicle? I cant pin it down, Ill call it sweet red flavour. Thick smooth yum!! This probably is the best spayside aged brew Ive ever had. the spayside and the chipotle seem to work perfectly together. Earth, wood, chocolate, red stuff, the end.

One of the tastiest brews Ive ever had. Pours a purely opaque black with a finger of dark tan head. The nose is sweet and woody with a hint of smoky sultry barrel and a massive roast atop notes of chocolate, vanilla, coffee and scotch. The middle is sweet and almost syrupy with notes of subtle chocolate and vanilla and a French roast espresso bean coming through. The finish is dry with medium bitterness from the roast (no hop detected really) and a lingering earthy wooden note. This is a really complex brew with a great array of flavors. Scotch wood lingers in the aftertaste with a big torrefaction coffee flavor. Full bodied and almost syrupy. Drinks like an Imperial Stout, but only 6.6%. WOW

In the end I like this version better despite the near total fade of the pepper effect. Black with a medium brown cap and sparse spotting. The sweet strength of the speyside dosage has not entirely killed the pepper like the flavour had happen to it. Mellow scotch notes showing vanilla, borderline grains and apple, deep nonsweet roast, maraschino cherries, biscuit, dark chocolate somewhere maybe and maybe even a relative to soy sauce... not sure but it all smells good minus the lack of chipotle that was so prominent in the regular version. The first thing that hits in the flavour is a sweet red fruit thing that does morph into the veggie pepper flavour uniformly. The heat comes mainly near the finish but in a mellow way. Smooth and soft mouthfeel and taste. Plenty of hard roast and vanilla and chalk, fuck balls - Suicidal Tendencies: Controlled by Hatred.... how did I forget about this song for years? Scotchness, xnerg. Yes, xnerg. Finishes strong and clean with lots of roast, a bit of scotch woodiness, a slight heat and a drying end.

375 ml green bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of milk chocolate, scotch, vanilla, roastiness, chipotles and dark fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark chocolate, scotch, roastiness, vanilla, light chipotle and light fruittiness with a smooth lingering chocolate scotch finish.

Appearance is opaque black, 1/2in cappucino head, sticks nicely to the glass. Nose of bakers chocolate, honey and butterscotch from the whisky, some peppers. Pretty one dimensional though. Tastes of chocolate and coffee as par for the course. Some oak, but if I didnt know this was Speyside aged, I wouldnt have guessed. Mouthfeel is coating and pretty much on cue for a porter. No complaints.  Overall, it drinks really well and is very well balanced, especially for being a pepper beer. However, its not terribly complex, which is a shame.

375ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a smallish dark tan head, which lasts fairly well and leaves good lacing. Bitter dark chocolate and coffee notes are blended with the peaty, maritime tang of Speyside scotch and the smoky heat of chipotle chilli in an unusual but very pleasant aroma. Mild herbal hops mix with more powerful chipotle smokiness up front before giving way to smooth, dark malt notes of black coffee and dark chocolate. The Speyside barrel ageing becomes more evident towards the finish, with a definite flavour of peat and faint brine notes. The chipotle asserts itself strongly at the end, leaving a lingering smoky heat. On paper the combination of porter, chilli and whisky does sound a bit odd, but it works very well. The result is an unusual but very impressive beer.

(375ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a small beige head.  Aroma of DEET, bourbon, chilies, caramel, and chocolate.   Flavor of roasted malt, bourbon, chocolate, chilies, smoke, bread, wood, and caramel with a dry finish.

Appearance: Pours out a simple-looking, black body with a smallish, dark tan head.

Smell: Moderately roasty, smoky aroma staked by reserved notes of chipotle peppers, peat-smelling Speyside whiskey, chocolate, and caramel.

Taste: Essentially roasted malts with a fair amount of upfront sweetness and a touch of semi-sweet chocolate chunks. Heat from the added peppers begins slinking in, building on the tongue. Noted smoke element contributed by the malts as well as the chipotles. Little hints of sea salt caramel, vanilla, earthy peat. Dry finish with some lingering pepper heat.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: I thought it was alright. Yep, just alright.

500ml bottle in a lager glass.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, whiskey, some hints of chipotle but not a lot, and some floral hops.  Flavour the same with a lot of whiskey.  Thick texture. A really good beer.

12.7 oz bottle and served in Duvel snifter: Pours basically black with a deep tan frothy lasting head and nice lacing. The aroma has notes of Scotch whisky, oak, vanilla bean, peat smoke, leather, Cavendish pipe tobacco, bakers chocolate, walnut, green apples, grapefruit, pine needles, a tad catty, and a hint of sea salt... no aroma of any Chipotle peppers. The taste is basically a nice deep robusta porter aged in a floral Speyside barrel with nutty and earthy components throughout. It is not till the sip is long gone that a MILD spicy heat comes about. It works it magic but I sit here still wanting more... much more. The palate is expected ashy and soft. Add a bit more Chipote, a bit more smoke and less green apple this would be a big hit. That said I would gladly still spend the monies for the other versions of this brew.

Poured into a snifter. This one was quite pricey at $12.

4.5 A: Black color. Three fingers of medium brown, frothy/creamy head. Retention is very good and a healthy sized ring of lacing is left behind.

4.5 S: I love me some chilis and this beer has the chipotles way up in the forefront. After that theres ample chocolate. The whiskey isnt very strong. If I hadnt read the label, I probably wouldnt have even detected it. Supple roastiness and maybe a touch of oak and caramel. I dont think Id be this impressed if the chipotles werent done perfectly.

3.5 T: The flavors dont mesh nearly as well in the taste. Foremost, the whiskey seems to be a bit off as it gives out a leathery tanginess that I dont quite care for. Too much peat as well. The chilis are done very well again though. They add a great flavor while being reserved with the heat. The chocolate and roastiness are congruent with the peppers. Moderately powerful smokiness. I think if I got a hold of the regular version, Id like it better.

3.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Could use some more creaminess. Tannic astringency on finish.

3.5 D: This was a tasty beer, but I think its mostly due to the peppers. The barrel aging did not improve this beer and I feel confident saying that without having had the original.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-04-2012 02:41:20

Pour dark brown, almost black, with a big, creamy frothy and long lasting tan head.
Aroma is quite roasted, with coffee, chocolate, vanilla, soy sauce, chilies and spices, oatmeal and whiskey. 
Taste is sweet, with a semi-long roasted finish.
Semi-watery body, with a lively carb.

Bottle to oversized tulip. Looks good; dark and opaque with thin lacing. Smells good too; The whiskey barrels are pleasant, but you pick up the pepper on the back end. Tastes solid (I didnt want to say "good" again). Nice flavors from the barreling with a mild, pleasant pepper experience. Mouthfeel is decent. Overall, a tasty brew.

Heavy roasted aroma and coffee-colored head. Both the whiskey and chipotle character are well-balanced and not overpowering. The heat lingers and builds as the beer warms, and I noticed I still had a little pepper in my chest a few minutes after finishing. Very good.
Bottle shared at the RBWG in Austin.  Dark pour with a tan head.  Nice addition of woody flavors and definite moss, but a little weaker than expected.

Bottle shared by a friend as part of the reprieve following the Hopsnobbery Collectives first (and last) Crappy Beer Tasting on 2/29/12. Pitch black pour with a thin light brown head. Malty nose with notes of apple, booze, chocolate and slight pepper. Chocolate malt flavor followed closely by whiskey and smoke before a boozy finish with a slight apple accent.
Bottle shared during RBWG 2012  Black with no head or lacing. Smokey, peat, dark malts and chocolate. Nice.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours viscour black with a small mocha head. Lasts duration and leaves some spotty lacing. Sweet vanilla and dark, bitter chocolate mingle with green herbal tones and spiced whiskey. Lots of peppers at the back end of it all. Quite complex. Dark cocoa powder on the tongue to begin with. The peppers come in and out on the palate with quick additions of light whiskey, chocolate, and back end herbal tones. Quite easy drinking even with the slight heat at the back end of palate. Nice carbonation. The beer comes together nicely. So far these texas ranger beers have been fantastic and this is no exception

2/25/12. Bottle I shared at RBWG 2012. Black pour with a small tan head. Bold aroma full of peat with some charcoal and chocolates. Slightly sweet chocolate entry followed by a boatload of peaty smokiness and then a bit of charcoal. Not bad.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with small off white head. The aroma is smoke and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel with smoke and chocolate with nice dry finish.

Bottle. Blackish beer with a brown head. Chooclate and rich malt aroma with whiskey. Whiskey and toffee flavor with rich malt and light chocolate. Medium bodied. Whiskey and toffee lingers with rich malt, light chocolate and light chilis.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar, CopenhagenBlack color, with dark brown head, not persistent. Mild aroma of sweet chocolate, and light roasted malts, covered by something that seems ripe apples. Medium body; with the dark chocolate flavor there is a light fruity sweetness that seems out of place; the chili pepper is present in mild form, providing a gentle feeling, comparable to the alcohol in other beers; medium alcohol feeling, that may be given by the whiskey cask.Chaotic beer, lacking of cohesion.

Solid, medium sized brown head with very good retention and some spotty lace.Appears to be black in color. Heaven knows its actually brown, sheesh. nose of chocolate, light smoke, pepper and roast. Body is almost medium, lil oily, soft carbonation. Thin whisky flavors along with light roasted pepper notes, light chocolate and woody otes. Fleeting, smokey roasty finish. Really thought the regular version more enjoyable. Bottle from statelineliquors.

At the warm tasting, thanks Ariel, pours orange to deep red with almost no head, aroma of molasses, caramel, dried fruits, woos, scotch, flavor of malt, bread, caramel, nuts, roasted tones and nice warming spiciness, medium bodied, nice

Pours pitch black with a thick mocha head...nice lacing and retention.  Aroma has rich chocolate, a hint of dark fruit, and mildly boozy whiskey notes.  Flavor has bitter bakers chocolate, a subtle hint of dark fruit, and mildly smoky roastiness with just a hint of oak and a hint of peppery burn.    Mouthfeel is medium and silky with a dry, very roasty, bitter finish that has just a hint of smoky burn.  Interesting beer!

Bottle. Pour is black with a thin brown head. Aroma has notes of whiskey, toasted oak, vanilla, peated malt, smoke. Tastes sweet with chocolate, chilies, whiskey, burnt malt, leading to a dry almost ashy finish.
scura buona schiuma  media persistenza naso legermente affumicato lieve legno caffe una spezato lieve picante

Bottle sample as "Mikkeller Barrel Aged Chipotle Porter"at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Pours black, opaque, tan foam. Coffee, peanut butter and roast aroma, brilliant chili-chocolate taste, smooth, long aftertaste and full body. I love it.

12.7 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch tan head.  The head stays around a little while, and theres a decent amount of lacing.  The brew smells like smoky whisky, dark chocolate, roasted malt, and a bit of chilies.  It tastes like bittersweet chocolate, roasted malt, smoky/peaty whisky, oak, and some light chilies.  The chili flavor does get stronger as the beer warms up, but its not close to being overpowering at all.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit creamy and coating, and has moderate, soft carbonation.  It certainly goes down easy enough.  I think its a pretty good brew.  Its pricey at $11.99 a bottle, but Id probably buy it again at that price.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. As "Mikkeller Barrel Aged Chipotle Porter". Black with a light brown head. Powerful burnt aroma of dark chocolate, whiskey and some spiciness with chili peppers notes. Sweet burnt flavor with dark chocolate, some chili peppers and a dry roasty finish with a bit of hot pepper feel. Full-bodied. Nice.

Good stuff that doesnt taste much different then the original.  The barrel aging resulted in a light peaty smokyness and slight woody tones.  Base beer is still great stuff with subtle pepper flavor and a great base porter.

This is ridiculously impressive. Got a new respect for Mikel and his borrowing of others equipment. The barrel aging doesnt overwhelm at all, it is a trifecta of balance between the chilis, the porter malts, and the barrel aging. NICE!
Massive Mikkeller pt.2. Dark pour, jet black with brown head. Big notes of bourbon and chili peppers here. Chocolate flavor is pretty heavy as well. A slow sipper but very enjoyable.

Pours a dark chocolate brown that appears pitch black and completely opaque in the glass with a 1.5 finger mocha head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Streaks of lacing left behind. 

Bold roasted malt aroma with a nice barrel presence that doesnt overpower the elements of the base beer. Some toasted oak and vanilla along with a sweet booze/whiskey presence. Underneath there is a slightly smokey, meaty dark malt presence with a strong dark chocolate character along with some oatmeal, toffee and chili powder. The chipotle presence is subtle in the nose allowing the other notes to come through. 

Slightly chewy medium body with a nice balance of barrel, whiskey, roasted malt and chili. Not quite as complex as the aroma suggests but there is a lot going on here. The Speyside whiskey is well integrated into the flavor with some sweet booze that gives off little heat. Theres also some dry, toasted oak that is complimented by a nice roasted malt presence. Slightly smokey with hints of bacon, toast, dark chocolate, caramel and toffee. There is a decent amount of sweetness from the whiskey and chocolate notes countering the dry/roasted character. The chipotle peppers are most prominent toward the back end of the palate but again, this flavor is well integrated into the flavor without overpowering everything. A subtle touch of peppery heat that goes really well with the silky chocolate, roasted malt and whiskey barrel flavors. 

Given Mikkellers reputation I was skeptical that this might turn into a whiskey or chili bomb but its surprisingly well balanced and complex. Considering all thats going on, its still pretty easy to drink, although the chipotle heat intensifies as it warms.

My wife says it tastes like chlorine water.

Thanks to Armin for sharing - gusher - fizzy black pour - thin ring of lace - looks like cola - deeply chocolately aroma, slight roast, a hint of oaky tannins, but hardly any whiskey - flavor is semi tart and bittersweet up front - quite a bit of dry, peaty whiskey notes follow - high carbo - bittersweet finish - the spice comes in strong in the finish, complimenting the light alcohol - nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2013 January 2012. Bottle @ Brandons, courtesy of Arminjewell. Huge thanks! Gusher. Deep brown appearance with a big dark brown head. Dark chocolate, moderately smoky malty, very light chili, celery veggie, roasty aroma. Somewhat spicy chili, hugely roasty, chocolate malty, peat whiskey, smoky, light veggie flavor. Carbonated mouth feel.(3.3)
April 2013. Tried again aged 16 months later and honestly, its tasting really nice right now. Veggie notes are nearly nonexistent with some nice chili spiciness. Theres a large amount of Scotch along with chocolate and caramel. (3.9)

Gusher out of the bottle is dark brownish almost black with nice creamy tan head and it goes away fairly fast, but fairly nice looking.  Aroma has notes of whiskey, toffee, caramel, hints of slight chili and pepper notes, touch of bakers chocolate and slight earthy notes, really nice smelling.  Taste is a nice mix of dusty cocoa powder, hints of chipotle chili but goes away quickly into the slight peat and oaky whiskey, hints of coffee and roast, earth finishing fairly bitter.

Bottle via StateLine... The regular version of this was my favorite beer of 2010, so this led to high hopes for this beer. But.... when I opened it,  it smelled like a homeless guy who drinks whisky all day.... Strait whiskey! Black in color, decent little head that faded quickly. Taste wise the whisky is not a prevalent as the nose... Nice tasty roasted malts, slight chocolate, but the peppers take a back seat to the whisky. The whisky adds a nice touch to it but I like the regular version better. Smooth creamy body which makes it very enjoyable to drink. Overall. Glad I got to try this beer, but I will stick to the non barrel-aged version. PS: I hope this is the right version.... my danish is a little on the weak side

24th September 2011Borefts Beer Festival 3. Opaque black beer. Little bubbly brown head. Crispy palate. Dark malt - crisp and not bitter or roasty. A little emulsion paint from the barrel aging. Mild speyside comes through - quite well balanced. Mild chilli heat in the finish. Not fierce though. Ok.

Bottle. Pour is pretty much black with a thin brown head.  Aroma is fruity, coffee roasted malt, light vanilla, light smoke, and a touch of milk chocolate.  Really nice aroma.  Flavor is smooth chocolate malt, light fruitiness, faint coffee notes, and a long milk chocolate finish with a hint of smoke and a very light chili burn at the end.  Awesome
Bottle. Black with a creamy light brown head. Scotch forward on the aroma with chocolate and pepper aroma. Tastes of chocolate scotch light pepper smokey peaty taste. Quite good.

Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma has a good complexity with cocoa, raisins, figs, nice caramel fudgy thing gong with vanilla hints, chocolate and roast. Very nice aroma indeed. Taste is nice and roasted, caramel, chocolate and cocoa, hints of wood, more whisky impressions than the aroma with a smoky touch, also vanilla and dark fruits and the finish showcases a bit of the chili with a warming sensation on the tongue. Better than the bourbon version, but the brandy cocoa vanilla version still takes it all the way to the bank.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Boreft Beer Festival 2011: Jet black with a small tan head. Aroma of licorice, spice and pepper. Sweetish licorice and chocolate flavour with pepper and a touch of whisky.

Loved the unbarreled version... if anything this needs to go in bourbon or just plain oak barrels.  The peat finish and the oxidation/soy character seem to be a bit at odds with the beauty of this beer with less age on it.  Still love that Mikkel nailed the heat of the peppers, really magnificent but not my fav of the bunch.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor for sharing. Pours black with a small creamy mocha head. Aroma is rich sweet chocolate, some bitter cocoa and a little smokiness with the light chipotle and oaky wood notes. Flavor starts with a strong woody oak and earthy character, quickly picking up the roasty espresso, chocolate and ashy character, some of the chipotle comes out through the finish which retains the woody quality. Medium full body and a soft carbonation. Pretty tasty beer,

Pours viscously to a jet-black beer with an ultra-dark beige head; oozing spirit and old barn aromas; antique dealers and maltwhisky-sipping customers. Rich... coffeebeans and black chocolate. Dry, very roasted and heating immediately up after swallowing. Vanilla, coffee and cacao, roasted and sweet (-alcoholic). Very onctuous, thick creamy and alcoholwarming. The hot feeling - immediately upon tasting - however, registers as chili only after a considerable time. Undeniably good, but Im developping a déjà-goûté feeling. And with a Speyside, Id somehow expected more fireworks.
Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours dark brown with no head. Aromas of single malt and oak. Full bodied. Flavors of smoke, scotch whiskey, oak and a little pepper. Very nice.

Bottle from City Beer. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head and a treacle and whiskey aroma. There is a dry chocolate and treacle flavor with a warm peppery alcohol finish. Lots of scotch in this one.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and whisky aroma. Roasted malty chocolate, chili and whisky flavor. Roasted malty spicy chili and chocolate finish with hints of whisky.
Bottle. Black fine head. Smoky honey aromas. Wiskey chocolate flavours. Taste a lot stronger due to the barrel storage. Gentle complex super brew.

Excellent, dark pour for the style with a nearly black body and a full, dense, creamy, dark tan head which is very nearly fully lasting and leaves thick, frothy lace rings.  The nose is pleasantly not overly Speyside in nature which is a great start for me; very smoky (both from the chipotle and the scotch), bakers chocolate, burnt caramel, some burnt dark breads, faint figs, and light vanilla.  The barrels seem to drown out some of the malts from the flavor; light bakers chocolate, still very smoky, chipotle towards the finish, malt flavoring, dry oak, and some roasted coffee in the back.  The palate is seemingly less than medium, watery, silky, and nearly lively.  The beer finishes long with chocolate syrup, dark coffee roast, and chipotle heat.  I actually just saw the "Barrel Aged" and instantly was excited, but I got home and noticed it was the Speyside version.  However, the scotch was quite subdued in the nose.  The original is better but this is very nice as well.
Pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, whiskey, chocolate and green pepper. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, chilli, whiskey and green pepper.

38cl, new exclusive Danish brew Anno 2011, with chili peppers, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex spicy Porter, spicy/roasted and slightly smoked/woody, not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good and original brew, yet very expensive!

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2011. Pours a pitch black beer with a weak hocolate head. The aroma is malt, roasted, sweetness, chocolate, soy and notes of green pepper. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is chiliwarmth and sweetness. Overall a good beer.

Angenehmer Malzantrunk mit Noten eines vollen Aschenbechers, sprich eine sehr trockene Rauchigkeit. Dann aber weich mit minimaler alkoholischer Schärfe, sehr angenehm. Darüber hinaus ist der Abgang lange und weniger trocken als zuvor. 10/12/11/11//12

How many disparate flavors can you jam into one beer?  Smoke, spice, chocolately sweetness, hoppy bitterness; this beer has them all and somehow manages to establish its own voice.  A decent one at that.  BBF, 2011.

pitch black, with small tan head, Aroma, meaty, vanilla, light smoke, whiskey, oak, light sour cream, grassy, earthy, liquorice, coffee, savoury, roasted, light vegetables, light dusty, medium mouthfeel, taste upfront is vegetal, herbal, then roasted,dry, and ends with small tingly chili sensation on the back of the palate, spicy, the smoke is almost gone compared to the original version, vanilla, stale coffee, wood, whiskey, grassy. some hops, fruity chilitaste, earthy, dry aftertaste, quite balanced

On tap at borefts 2011.  black with lasting tan head.  Dont normally like the texas rangers as got too much liquorice and tar for me.  This has those but the speyside lifts it.  Thats very good.  Quite roasty.  Decent beer. 3.8

On tap. Pours black with a beown head. Aroma is very spice with the chilli up front, some earthy notes, light smoke, roasted malts, liquorice, cocoa nibs, some dark dried fruits and a barrel quality is there too. Taste is sweeter with chocolate, dark sweet fruits, chilli still there, coffee, earth wood, liquorice and roasted malts. Nice balance between the sweetness and spicyness.

Tasted on 11/11/11 from a capped 375mL bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors.  Pours a completely opaque oily black with a very thick and long-lasting brown head that slowly recedes to rocky lace, leaving thick residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is full of vanilla and darkly roasted chocolate malt, a vegetal squash or pumpkin note, and a spicy, smokey chipotle aroma.  The flavor is full of milk chocolate syrup, vanilla and coconut oak, a strange vegetal flavor, and a tinge of spicy chili pepper on the back of the palate.  The body is full and creamy with a long, dark chocolate, vanilla, and lightly spicy chili pepper finish.

09-NOV-2011, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
High lasting fluffy head on black body.
Nose is alcohol, fruits (chili?), roasted or even burned malts and then whisky. Fantastic:) Taste is even more of the same. The malts are stronger here with chocolate and coffee. Chili kicks in, as always with a fair amount and enough to be felt and tasted.
Ends hoppy bitter with a long whisky/chili afterburner. Fantastic effort.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, Viktoriagade 8BC, kld., DK-1655 Copenhagen, Denmark.Clear dark black colour with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige to light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, chocolate, coffee, smoke - tar, sweet medicine - peat, light to moderate hoppy. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, dark malt - hop bitter, roasted - burnt - tar bitter, dry, chile fruit notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110916]

Pitch black pour, small brown head. Aroma has whisky, banilla, rasisins, some peat, port, dried fruits, subtle alcohol kick, fermented figs. Taste is similar with smoke, whisky, roast, quite subtle, figs, port, raisins, figs, figs, figs, figs, figs, dry finish.

Shared a 375ml bottle with the wife.
Aroma:smoke, chocolate, whiskey
Taste: slight smoke, chocolate, whiskey, slight sour notes, some roasted malts
A great beer, we enjoyed it a lot.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2011 375 at the bayou. Speyside edition. Pure black medium brown head. A sweet scotch nose some smoke and vanilla. Awesome flavor dark fruit, smoke, whiskey, vanilla, so damn rich. Little heat or peppers. This is a great barrel aged stout, really showcases Speyside.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar. Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is hard roasted malt, chocolate, whisky, peat and light chili. The flavour has a mild chili burn and the hard roasted malt is in front. Notes of chocolate, whisky, wood and light coffee.
Pour at the Borefts Bier Fest 2011. Dark color, thick pour. Bourbon in the sip. Very very nice.
Pitch black, opague colour with a brown head. Smells roasty, coffee, chocolate and cocoa. Tastes just like you would expect from the smell. Full chocolate body, good carbo.
Draught @ Borefts 2011. Black, with a tan head. Coffee, caramel, dark chocolates, bourbon, oak and vanilla in the aroma. Dense with lots of carbonation. Good one.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Rated on 5.10.2011.
Pours a pitch black colour with a beautiful brown head with good retention. Aroma of sweet toasted malts, smoke, oak and chocolate. Flavour of roasted malts, oak, vanilla, chocolate and light hops. Full bodied, smooth mouthfeel and a long, roasty, mild chili-burning finish. Whisky is quite well hidden but it does smoothen this nicely.
Bottle @ BBF2011. Black pour, thin tan head. Aroma is roasty, bourbon, leather and vanilla. Flavor is bitter roasted bourbon and peat with a very nice spicy afterbite. Very nice.
pitch dark, small  smooth brown head.wood, peat, roasted malts, whiskey. Aroma. Strong.8 flavor is wood roasted malts, whiskey, strong considering its abv7

On tap. Pours black and opaque with a small light brown head leaving a discreet lacework. Sweet roasted malt in the nose - and sweet whisky notes. Quite a rich body, a little low in carbonation, sweet roasted malt, somwwhat oxidized barrel character where the whisky feels smooth and warming. Hardly any bitterness. 011011

Sampled at Borefts Beer Festival @ De Molen, Bodegraven. Full light brown head on top of a pitch black, opaque colored beer. Smell coffee, roasty, smokey, caramel, chocolate. Taste coffee, bitter, roasty, smokey, caramel. Great carbo, good ABV, full body. Great beer!

From bottle @ BBF 2011. Deep dark brown color. Very malty aroma with oak and whisky notes. Very sweet, almost sugary flavor with dried fruit, caramel and whisky notes. A little bit too much of everything.
Leathery aroma. Taste of chocolate mainly. Some leather aftertaste with coffee and alcohol.

Draft at BBF 2011, courtesy of Mikkels crew.  But where was Mikkel?  Dark murky brown color, brown head.  Aroma of vanilla, walnuts, smoke, chocolate.  Taste is chocolate with chili warmth, kind of like mole sauce in Mexico.  Whisky comes in near the finish.  Nice.
Tap @ Borefts Beer Festival, 2011. Pours black with a small creamy head and lacings. Chocolate, roast, chili and oak. Smooth and roasted flavor with a bit of wamth. Harmonic and nice.

On tap (the last glass poured of this) at Boreft Beer Festival, De Molen, Bodegraven, Netherlands, 24.09.11   Dark and warming but easy to drink, smooth with the gentle warmth of the chillies flooding through, decent beer with nice roasty and maltiness and the chocolate combining nicely with the chillies. Very pleasant beer.    A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov14  3.7
Black coloured beer, to small head. Liquorish, roasted malts, chocolate. Alcohol kicks in harder then expected with this abv.
Sampled at BBF 2011.  Black pour with brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and coffee.  Same aspects in flavour.  Shockingly good for the reasonably low ABV.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2012 Black with a small creamy head. Chocolate cake, cream and raspberries in the end. Really complex and developing throughout. Great ending, even with the fairly mild nose. Never got the chilly, luckily. Top beer. (At Borefts)
From tap. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and light smoked. Mild chili and dark roasted malty and toasted breadish. Spiced and roasted dark malty finish.

Bottled. Black coloured. Dense brown head. Wood, spice, roast, sweetness, vanilla, smoke and vague meat in the aroma. Flavour of bacon, smoke, meat, vague chili, wood, roast, vanilla, Medium to full bodied. Dry roasted and smoked end. Nice.
tap at de olen ... deep black ...  big roast malt ..big whiskt roast ... lots of rost nalt ... over hevyof whisky ... dark roast

Bottle at jannik.
Black coloured with a huge beige head.
Roasted aroma of caramel, dark chocolate, oak and whisky.
Roasted flavour of caramel, dark chocolate, oak and whisky.
Roasted finish.

Draft. A black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of whiskey, peated smoke, soy sauce, and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of chocolate, chilis, roasted malt, soy sauce, and peated smoke as well as a bit of whiskey, leading to a dry roasted finish.

Bottle at Karanfil Hotel, Güzelcamli. Pitch black - brown head. Light sharpness. Chili notes. Smokey. Peated. Oiley. Burned. Light sharpness. Iod. Licorice. High malty. Chocolate. Ok bitterness. Nice.

Tap @ Mikkeller, Cph.
Deep black with a small, creamy, beige film head. Aroma has lots of whiskey, chocolate, liqourice, light burning chili. A slight bit of vegetable. Medium carbonation, kinda light and fairly dry mouthfeel. Flavour is mildly sweet, some slight tartish oak, chocolate, mild roasted and just a slight hint of chili. Good, but the bourbon and the original are much better.
Nose is sweet malt, medium cane sugar, some oak, burnt notes, feel is mediumwatery, carb is medium, taste is medium chili, weak sour notes, cane sugar, port, decent dry malt, some wood
